commentBody: More fun for the constructor than the solver.
Enjoyed it..enough of a stretch but not so much that I couldn‚Äôt get it.
Favorite clues were 43A and 32D.  Dug deep for 9D, which was my only entry in the first 2 minutes. Crunchy and fun!

I went to the dentist this morning for a crown (sadly not the fun kind), so novocaine was quickly entered. Lots of playful misdirection and just the right amount of resistance for an enjoyable Saturday solve. Congratulations to Mr. Lieberman for publishing a grid for every day of the week -- quite the accomplishment.
Insanely clever. Really enjoyed the light bulb moments.

This one initially struck me as really hard.  I started out with only two acrosses.  Luckily the downs offered a little purchase and it came to together after that.  Remembering how to spell ORESTEIA helped a bit.  I loved ARMRESTHOG, having encountered a few in my time, it was good to put a name to them.  I chuckled at AWMAN, but only because my five year old grandson has taken to saying that. ELFHAT for felt in the Christmas spirit was one of several clever clues.  I bogged down a bit in the SW because I tried low and ebb tides before RIPTIDES.  I also faltered a bit because I thought that a sty was the place with an appropriate final vowel sound
Kudos to Mr. Lieberman. This was an excellent and very fair test for me -- took longer than my average, but this was a creative puzzle and a fun challenge. Well done.

Loved this one, right on my wave length. 

Also love that ORESTEIA - which I had never heard of and taught me something new - was crossed with reasonable stuff. Ditto MYRNA.  Weird proper names are fine when they don't cross.

I saw a grid that I thought was pointing to an easy Saturday, but I was (gladly) wrong.  The clueing had me *just* off balance, looking for wordplay where there was none, and vice versa.  That's just good construction.  I'm always puzzled when crosswords like this get labeled a 'slog' - yes, I was way over my average solve, but I was having fun the whole time.

I'm with you Caitlin!! I was stuck at the gas station for awhile!!
Fun puzzle, definitely made me think!!

The *perfect* Saturday crossword, and now I have my research lined up for the rest of the weekend: check out ORESTEIA (which I initially thought was an ingredient in fat-free potato chips), OMOO (following yesterday's COWSHED, nice one, Will!), to say nothing of MYRNA and ZADIE and ELFHATS (???). 

Thanks, Michael, and I can't wait for your next oeuvre!

"Why am I here again?"
"You're waiting on tech support to show up."
"Oh, I see IT now."

("Yeah. Just remember to pay them in cache.")
Having extensively studied early Chinese history, the SALTTAX clue is not particularly accurate. I hope the constructor didn‚Äôt just base the answer off of that slate article!

Names should not intersect with names.

0/10
Too obscure at every turn to be any fun.

Excellent puzzle, and memorable to me because my streak just hit 1000.  

I read the Oresteia trilogy for "Masterpieces of Western Literature," which I took as freshman in 1976.  "Omoo" was one we read for a course on Melville and Twain.  Neither of those stumped me (and both are much worth reading), but I kept thinking "stressate" was one word, not "stress ate."  Very pleasantly surprised to get the happy music on the first try.
Boy, that was hard!

Toughest Saturday in a while. Kinda shocked I got the Gold Star, actually. I was down to CP_/ORESTEI_ and _IRK/_A_D_/I_EST and took my three best guesses. Still don't understand why SPOT and IDEST are the right answers though

When are they going to post the names of the winners of the Puzzle Mania mega-crossword contest? Or have I missed it?

This seems awfully late.
wow

A fine 45 minutes I thought, though after lying down for that long I now feel like a late afternoon nap.

46D Namely = idest, i dest, id est, ide st or ides t? What am I missing?

Excellent, excellent, excellent. Went very quickly for me because of several hooks which happened to be gimmes for me, but what fantastic wordplay. The clues for NOVOCAINE and STRESS ATE alone were worth the price of admission, and the felt in ELF HATS was such a clever misdirect. 

The perfect Saturday puzzle.

Loved this!  I felt challenged, and had to dig deep for more than half the answers.  But it never felt impossible.  An excellent Saturday puzzle, with lots of answers that were unusual and creative.  

Bravo!  

And thank you to the powers that be for choosing this one!

Absolutely destroyed my Saturday average clocking in at 104 minutes, but I got there with looking anything up so am very happy.

NW consumed all that time. Had silk tax as the Great Wall financer and aislepacer for undesirable airplane seat mate, even though an aisle pacer wouldn't annoy me at all.

@dutchiris

Thank you for your beautiful Paris memory. I only saw your Friday comment about it just now. It read like an idea for a film I'd watch.

About today's puzzle:

I enjoyed most of the tricky clues, but overall the was too hard for me to complete without lookups. As usual, proper nouns and abbreviations were my nemesis. One of the names I did *not* have to look up was NOEL Coward - I'm not a theater person, but my wife and I stayed at a hotel in his former villa, Blue Harbor, on Jamaica in 2011, and I learned the name there. Chilling in a hammock by an infinity pool overlooking the Caribbean will forever be one of my fondest memories.

Some clues were beyond me for cultural reasons. For example, Christmas elfs (elves?) are not a thing over here, so the hat was a mystery to me (felt gave me hat, but what kind of three letter hat is associated with Xmas? None, to me).

NOVOCAINE is not sold here that I know of, and its clue was beyond arcane for me, anyway.

How is a MORTUARY a body shop? I get that a body shop is a place where a car's bodywork gets fixed, so clearly wordplay was intended, but how do mortuaries fix bodies? Is it about your grisly American custom of embalming? To me it feels like mutilation of a body rather than fixing it up... 

I only know UPC as a European internet service provider, but clearly that was not today's UPC. Could somebody please explain the clue 'Lines at a grocery store' solving to UPC

Having read the comments, I‚Äôll add this: How do you get from Michael Lieberman‚Äôs [brass] to GALL? Practice, practice, practice. Many Saturday puzzles may seem impossible to newer‚Äîor even intermediate‚Äîsolvers, but take it from those of us that have done a few hundred of them by now: They eventually become pure bliss to solve. 

Puzzle solving is like yoga. Your first class is pure torture. You stand there in (your pitiful version of) the warrior pose, feeling as awkward as you know you look, your quad burning so badly that you think it just might pop right out of your thigh, and you want to wipe that gentle smile of your instructor‚Äôs face as she‚Äôs telling you to feel oneness with your breath or what-the-heck-ever. 

A couple of years later, that class and the quad-bursting asanas are the best part of your week. 

Stick with the Saturday puzzles, folks. Your mental quads will get there.

At first glance, this one seemed as if it might be impossible, but while I‚Äôm not going to be bragging about my time üòâ, I did finish a fair bit below average for me, to my surprise. 
The gimmes of MYRNA and EMU made the NW corner fill in with not too much trouble, and that increased my confidence that the entire grid would be doable‚Ä¶ which, happily for me, it was! 

In addition to the aforementioned MYRNA, NOEL, GRETA, and OMOO were also quick fills that aided me in the solve. I think, as much as some folks like to complain about proper nouns as fill, it is often those there-can-only-be-one-answer clues that serve to open up a tough puzzle. Of course, it can be frustrating when you are unfamiliar with a crucial reference, but some fact-based questions have always been a part of puzzles‚Ä¶ and often are extremely helpful!

Can we start tracking how much of a puzzle we solved without hints? On this one I got all except the upper left (despite immediately figuring out ARMRESTHOG) but I just get the same blue star as if I'd autochecked from square one. I imagine this should be doable as we already get 50% and 75% completion popups.

Overall, a nice puzzle. I had almost nothing on the first pass, and guessed wrongly a number of times along the way, which slowed me down a bit. 

But despite all the good things in this puzzle, I have to complain about 30D and 46A. 

What has how a SASH fits got to do with Royalty outside of beauty pagents, which tend to be contests for those to whom the gendered term "King" doesn't apply?

And while "Consumed" is perfectly valid for ATE, I don't see how "with grief" is supposed to lead us to STRESS. I eventually got it from the crosses, but the clue makes no sense to me - question mark or not.

(As an aside, years and years ago I got curious about this OMOO novel that kept showing up in crosswords I was doing, so I requested it from the library. I can't remember if it was Wikipedia or the preface to that novel that told me it was a sequel, but also ended up reading Typee. My point is that if it wasn't for crosswords, I never would've know anything about Melville aside from Moby Dick).
I figured it out with crosses and three years of high school French, but citing the sixth verse of La Marseillaise in a clue is a bit obscure.
A challenging puzzle, which normally I love, but this one just didn't spark joy for me.

That was a slog for me. Whew! I liked ISEEITNOW because I saw it then. Fun moment!

MYRNA Loy in old movies ‚Äî sheer joy! I especially love the *Thin Man* series. 

HMART was fun because I read the book *Crying in H-Mart* by Michelle Zauner.  I tried to get my daughter to read it and she resisted. I worked some magic in the universe and ‚Äî viola! ‚Äî suddenly it was her book club‚Äôs next selection üòâ.

Many difficult entries for me, though. Got ‚Äòer done even if it was tough.

"Admire your puzzle"???  How about my puzzle admiring me?  Against all odds, I solved it, despite still being at sea about some clue/fill match-ups. I looked at NOVOCAINE, got the filling station connection, but number?  EYESOCKET was an early fill, but I found it so creepy I was prepared to take it out asap, and "Body shops" didn't exactly cheer me up, since I'm coming down with something (tested for COVID, but the revised test expir. date was a week ago, so who knows).

I'll admit that your imposing offense had some style, Michael Lieberman (I felt quite smug about the ORESTEIA and OMOO, and I'm always happy to see ELFHATS ‚Äîthey remind me of David Sedaris' stint at Macy"s), but now I think I'll take my VITAMINS, go to bed, and hope for a better tomorrow.

Thank you, Michael. It's just the whatever-it-is talking, which isn't your fault (but I regret not even feeling up to a little STRESS eating.

This one defeated me.

To me, 9D could've been any mix of letters, had no idea what that was, and I had CPL at 35A (an army Corporal works on a column, no?)

Passed the hour mark and checked puzzle for my second blue-star Saturday this month.

No one just ZIGs 

The rest was fine for me. 

Fair Saturday except for ID EST. That was not nice especially in ZADIE, DADA combo. 

Thanks

Obscure trivia is not my favorite, but when you can solve it with the crosses (and maybe a guessed letter or two), it's fine; and when those crosses are also clever wordplay, it more than makes up for it.

Crunchy, but in a good way. Took about 50% longer than my (recent) Saturday average.

Fitting, I think, that my 1000th in a row should be a little tougher than expected :)

This was a very challenging, very good puzzle.

I stared at it for so long, it eventually got up, came over and slapped me.

For a long time for 5D I had "roo", thinking the  Aussies didn't like jumpy things, and declared wipe them out like they did the Aborigines.

I should have realized that we're in EMU country.

I really enjoyed this one even though it took me ten minutes more than my average. At least for me, the last few Saturdays have been a bit on the too easy side.  So thank you Mr Lieberman for helping me blow away the cobwebs on this Saturday morning!

So, I sang La Marseillaise. Scratched head. Looked up the lyrics. That you sent me not to the second, not to the third, but to the sixth verse ! For that word !! Touch√© Mr. Lieberman. Touch√©. That's when I knew I would love this puzzle.

I‚Äôm the type of person who sticks with something until it‚Äôs done, no matter how difficult or frustrating. Sometimes this reaps great benefits, like the time I ended up with a beautiful self-tiled bathroom floor. But other times, it means I work and re-work a crossword puzzle far past the point of having any fun. 

It‚Äôs not the constructor‚Äôs fault as there was nothing unfair about it, but I should have let this one go.

Whew! That was difficult.  Took a nap after I stalled out in the upper middle. Rhine before Rhone. Theif before heist. GMs  before VPs. Something octane? No idea about the Greek? Or the trees.  Or the mart. Erased all the guess work and it finally came together on crosses.  This was my 2000th solve and I'm intentionally ending the steak at 1000.  It's been a mostly fun ride and this puzzle was a fun exclamation point for the streak.
Thanks Mr Lieberman. A fun workout.

Wow! This was as hard as the NYT first crossword I ever tried, but excellent cluing. I particularly enjoyed the wordplay, like PECLASSES, VITAMINS, RIPTIDES - real clues. 

But ..... some clues just too obscure for me, like the abbreviations and the hats. The US elf (with the stripey socks) invaded our shores a few years ago, and is strenuously marketed with toys, clothes and books, but it's not a huge part of the culture yet. Like Hallowe'en, it will expand and make money. 
So far, Valentine's Day remains directed at adults in a relationship, not at absolutely everyone. When an American friend once sent my small sons Valentine cards I was startled and did a "Yuk"!

Typical tough Saturday for me, and I had to cheat a bit to get going in more than a few places, but then managed to work out the rest form the crosses. Just a nice challenge overall. And of course my puzzle find today. This was a VERY unusual one. A Thursday from September 27, 2007 by Peter Wentz. Some theme clues and answers in that one: 17a - "90" PARENTHESES 32a - "3" POUNDSIGN 38a - "1" EXCLAMATIONMARK 45a - "7" AMPERSAND And then the reveal: "What is being held in 17-, 32-, 38- and 45-Across" THESHIFTKEY Wow. Here's the Xword Info link: https://xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=9/27/2007&g=45&d=A ...

Excellent Saturday, which required two passes, separated by sleep, for me.

*Crossword Revolution D4:  MORTUARIES

I felt a Funeral, in my Brain,
And Mourners to and fro
Kept treading - treading - till it seemed
That Sense was breaking through -

- E. Dickinson (Poem No. 340, 1st stanza)

* This is a Crosswords Saved the Day ‚Ñ¢ production.  All rights reserved.

Now *that* was a Saturday puzzle.

I decided to take pictures of my favorite puzzles so when it's time to vote next year, I'll have something to refresh my memory.  This is the first one in my 2025 folder.

[Holders of orbs] for EYE SOCKETS and [Body shops?] for MORTUARIES gave me a laugh and the many misdirects made for a welcome challenge.  

I hope to see more themeless puzzles from Michael.  This one really hit the SPOT.

My goodness, that was a beast. I can look back now it‚Äôs solved and appreciate the work that went into it. Not going to lie though, it was so hard for me that it left enjoyment far behind. So many unknowns, so few that I could take a stab at with a few crosses. Ironically EMUS about my only gimme today. The stack of AVEC, NOEL, CIA helped a little, but not that much as I hadn‚Äôt come across the numbing agent before.
I‚Äôm going to chalk this one up as a miss, glad that a lot of you have had fun with it.
A lot of clues I would be unhappy about normally. But I respect the setter's decision to fully commit and make an entire crossword in the style.
Fun and challenging, but is ‚Äústressate‚Äù actually a word?

Strands Thread.  Please see your way clear to posting no spoilers until we reach the View All Replies button.  


Strands #328
‚ÄúSeeing double‚Äù
üü°üîµüîµüîµ
üîµüîµ


Twice as much fun.

I live in France, and even I have to say that using a word ("avec") buried in the SIXTH verse of the Marseillaise is close to unreasonably obscure. I mean, I don't know a single French native who would know that reference, and it's their anthem for crying out loud!

Having said that, I was stumped, completely, at about halfway. Then, once I pulled the reveal lever, I thoroughly enjoyed the various wordplays and cleverness. I love the fact that sometimes it's not solving it but appreciating the creator's skill that's the point. Great time!
Excellent puzzle! Great to maintain brain flexibility!

Good puzzle, but a tough one for me. TIL "id est." I also could not, for the life of me, see "elf hats."  I did manage to come up with "avec," but only because that's one of the few French words I know that even remotely seemed to fit.

Oh, there were glimmers of beauty in the box (THRALL, X FACTOR, GESTALT, STREWS), and many thorny areas to happify the brain, but to me, the star was the cluing, rife as it was with wordplay.

OMG, I marked 15 wordplay clues that sparked joy when the answer pinged.  Fifteen!  Usually there are less than you can count on one hand.  Such clues hit my happy button, and today I felt like a kid in a playground.  

Freshness abounded in the cluing.  Even that fabulous clue for NOVOCAINE, where yes, ‚Äúnumber‚Äù has been used before to describe it, Michael took it one step farther with the ‚Äúfilling station‚Äù angle.  Chef‚Äôs kiss!

I like the grid design ‚Äì one never used before in a Times puzzle -- with 16 longs (answers of eight letters or more), bringing the fun and thrill of getting long answers with as few crosses as possible.

I love ARMREST HOG, a true debut answer, never having appeared in any of Crosslandia‚Äôs major venues. I don‚Äôt remember hearing this term before, but it‚Äôs perfect and now firmly ensconced in my lexicon.  

Michael, you satisfied my brain‚Äôs work ethic and entertained me to no end today.  Thank you for a stellar outing!
I feel very satisfied after completing this beautifully clued puzzle.
40% longer than average to complete this one.  Some very formidable clues.  Seemed like a higher number of clues ending in question marks.  Don‚Äôt know if anyone keeps up with that kind of thing.

Each confirmation of the particular wordplay at play in a clue this morning was worthy of a small ceremony.

Why am I here? To say this puzzle reminds me of the cruddy buildup I imagine happened in German u-boats.

Sublime.

Holy crunch, Batman!

Mr Lieberman, I dub thee
Captain Crunch.

Upsides were many. 
No idea what it did to my solving time average,
except it did *not* get lower.

And hubby, though slightly disgruntled,
had to help. A bunch.

He was so chuffed for knowing SALT TAX,
it almost made him less angry when I had
to tell him the one he was struggling with was
AMPERSAND.

Apparently, that is *exactly* why he hates puzzles.

It may be near lunchtime, 
but the streak stands.

(And I‚Äôm putting ALAI range in my pocket.
No gimme ‚ÄúJai __‚Äù this morn!)

Have a lovely day all!

Go Bills!
I had to use the Tricky Clues help today to get things moving, but once those were in the rest came together. Still pretty tough, though.

(Elf) hats off to all of you who solved this. I'm pretty good at these things -- I've solved four of the last five Saturdays, and only had to look up one clue in just one of those -- but, after 25 minutes of trying, I knew I'd never come close to completing today's. Really, really hard. (As others have noted, this makes up for several recent too-easy-for-late-in-the-week puzzles).
This was a tough one but hit my 1,000 day streak on it!!  WHEW!!

Very, very difficult but excellent puzzle imo. A lot of clever twists in the clues that had me saying ISEEITNOW once I got the answer. OVERPAR, AMPERSAND, and GESTALT were some of my favorites. I was determined to finish with no lookups but I had REDHATS instead of ELFHATS and finally needed ORESTEIA to set me straight (I vaguely remembered the name Orestes but that didn‚Äôt get me over the hump.) A long but ultimately satisfying solve.

ISEEITNOW!

Thought that often today. This one was a workout for me. Solved it unaided, but took me just shy of an hour. Didn't know ZADIE, and the the Z was my last entry. Felt that ZIG/ZADIE were just a bit more likely than JIG/JADIE.

Entered MARRIED right away for "Joined a union"---and then it took me way too long to recognize the correct SAIDIDO. 

In retrospect, I'm amazed I solved this one. ORESTEIA, GESTALT, XFACTOR, ELFHATS, DIRK, ALAI. Remarkable all the odd stuff crammed in the dark corners of my brain. Equally remarkable that I can (once in a while) even drag it out when needed.

Great Saturday puzzle!
As usual I just googled the proper nouns. Otherwise it takes too long and is boring.

Slow but steady for me. Periods of blankness, followed by inspiration, followed by an outburst of solving, followed by a period of blankness. Repeat. 
Hugely enjoyed this one for its clever cryptic cluing combined with proper nouns that were actually in my cultural wheelhouse. Was there a single clue relating to American sport, education or chain restaurant food (my usual downfalls)? Can't think of one. NOVOCAINE is an American trade name but very familiar in the UK. Not sure if Miracle-GRO is sold over here, but I seemed to know it once I got a cross.

Applause.
Not sure how I managed to solve this one, but once I got the southeast corner filled in other stuff started to fall into place.  A rewarding adventure.
Haha, I zagged when I should have zigged! Otherwise, apart from not at first seeing stress ate as two words, pretty good.

Wowie-Zowie, Herr Lieberman.  My cup of coffee got cold; after I whipped through the NW corner I hit a Jam, what with "La Marseillaise" and the Asian grocery store.  
I felt very smug, knowing OMOO and the ORESTEIA, but I put a DISH before the king (four-and-twenty blackbirds!) ....I didn't know whether to ZIG or ZAG.

ALAI clued as Mountains?  
"Photomontage art" for DADA?  AW, MAN!

I did complete the solve without help, but not without pain.  Might be time to update the dartboard!

Just on the same wavelength as Michael today ‚Äî objectively this looks like a hard one, but I saw ARMRESRT HOG immediately and it was pretty much off to the races after that. Several of the other longer entries, like MORTUARIES, HAIR SALON and EYE SOCKETS similarly came readily. STRESS ATE and ELF HATS were last to fall but even those came fairly quickly on the crosses. 

Thanks Michael for the fun and challenging-but-still-breezy Saturday.

That was brutal. I can't remember the last time I had to look things up in a puzzle. I learned a lot about the topography of Kyrgyzstan today.

I had lots of wrong guesses initially. Married instead of SAID I DO. Hejira instead of SHARIA. Door store instead of HAIR SALON. (I know, trust me, I know.) I guessed OMOO right away, but I doubted myself and left it blank.

I like a workout every once in a while, but hopefully we won't see another puzzle this difficult for quite some time. My ego can't handle it.

Wow, this was great!! Had to use all my skills for this one, right down to looking at the start of 31D and the start of 37A to figure out what letter was likely to fit in their cross (not that many readily follow both HA- and R-, and guessing that it was probably I is what allowed me to unlock the rest of the SW.) Still managed to get it a few seconds ahead of my Saturday average, too. 

Never in all my years of crosswording (or getting degrees in English, or being an English teacher) do I recall OMOO, but I got it with my last fill-in and thereby learned something I'll try to keep in mind going forward. 

Thank you for the Saturday-worthy crunch, Mr. Lieberman. More like this please!
Obtuse puzzles like this one, lacking any discernable theme or purpose, don't engender loyalty to the NYT crosswords.  Hey NYT, edit much?

Whew, finally finished it.  This was quite hard for me but I got through it and have no complaints.  Upper left was particularly tough.  A lot of clever and tricky cluing throughout.  In the end, nothing unfair and all solvable.

The column highlights some of the better ones - "number" is great.  I saw "joined a union" coming a mile away and was happy when it filled in.  Interesting that "to wit" fits where "id est" goes.  I guess to me the weakest answer is the very first one, arm rest hog.

Anyhow, a really good Saturday puzzle that nearly broke me.  A quick glance down shows some others were unhappy but I wouldn't know why.

____________________
Jesse Goldberg 8/28/2024 for Puzzle of the Decade
(emu filler)

riptIDes
tour guIDes
saID I Do

This was the IDEST puzzle ever!


Confidential to Sam Lyons: You are a wordsmith extraordinaire, appreciated and beloved by (almost)everyone here. I hope you won't be consumed with grief just because somebody lacks basic reading comprehension skills.
Thanks Michael for reviving the classics with ORESTEIA.

Cluing was out of this world - always a good sign to have question marks at the end of clues!   Favorites -

In the 80s or 90s, say
Body shops
Felt in the Christmas spirit
Novel technology
Holders of orbs
Consumed with grief

Great fun!

Remember folks, a puzzle is supposed to be puzzling, and this one is truly that. I solved it with no look-ups, but it took me 1 hour and 24 minbutes to do so. This is exactly what I needed amidst all the horrible things that are going on. Thank you for the respite.

Very crunchy indeed.

12D is perhaps the most diabolical misdirection I‚Äôve seen in 1700+ puzzles here.
Great Saturday puzzle and super misdirect cluing!

I love the point when my attitude changes from "I can't solve this without a look-up" to "It's doable on the crosses" and things start clicking in. EYESOCKETS, MORTUARIES, NOVOCAINE, and STRESSATE all went well with my coffee. A mordantly satisfying Saturday puzzle.

Wow, what an epic journey that was! Seriously challenging in the best way. Being able to claw out answers to trivia you don't know (e.g. 50A) from crosses you have to work at is crosswording at its best.

Really enjoyed the brain teasing clues like 12D and 43A. I think I only had two answers after my first pass, but the whole thing came together after a longer than usual solve.

Very challenging, and still working on it.  But not loving 59 across.  Even imprecisely, that is a unit, not a measurement.  Sort of like "price of a new car...Dollars!  Distance from New York to LA... Miles!"
Wow! and PHEW!! Truly entertaining. This may be the longest Saturday solve I've ever done. Loved solving it! Thanks for 50-down, wasn't so sure about it but it was right,after all
Tough one, took me an hour. Great clues, a nice challenge. Thanks.

Another Saturday puzzle that makes me think‚Ä¶hey, I can do these. Of course, next Saturday or the week after, I‚Äôm sure I will be slapped back down to my more familiar stumbling through the darkness. Some clever misdirects in this one, and a fun solve overall.
Tip of the cap to the constructor. Very difficult but very fair puzzle that took up a longer chunk of my day than expected!
Wow. i did it. Some whack stuff in there but also some fun stuff too....persistence and creative thinking paid off.

So much to like about this crunchy Saturday.

So many clever misdirects, causing frustration at first, but slowly giving way to pleasant "a-ha!" moments.

Anyone else feel mildly uncomfortable (in a good way?) about the cluing for MORTUARIES and EYE SOCKETS?

Enough "easy" entries (for me), so that there was always progress.

Fine job, Michael Lieberman!

Excellent Saturday. Started right out with ARMRESTHOG, but it wasn't going to be that easy! Had "married" before SAIDIDO, redtides before RIPTIDES. Ahh "number", as in to make something numb! ISEEITNOW! NOVOCAINE!
Homemade biscuits with honey, anyone?? Woke up with a craving. 
Well I could sit here all day with the sun streaming in the dining room window, but it's time to clean.
A perfect Saturday! It should take up a good chunk of a lazy weekend morning and it did just that. Thanks!

I'll have to check my photo album, but I think I took the same picture of the Great Wall...minus the newlyweds. That section (Badaling) is just an hour's bus ride from Beijing proper, so it's the most visited. I had lunch at a KFC that was done up to look like a traditional hutong building, with tile roof and everything. I did not check my receipt for the SALT TAX.
Whew!

Oh my... Oh, oh my... After being subscribed to the NYT Crossword Puzzle for almost 7 years, today marks the first Saturday I ever solved on my own! 

I have been having some stressful days and the solving sound just made me smile for the first time in a while! 

I loved it. The clues were so clever. Thanks so much, I am over the moon!

This week was strange--my longest time was on Tuesday. 

I did not take time to comment then, but did scan the comments and saw I was an outlier. It was not a hard puzzle for most.

After fly specking, then checking the spelling of proper names, I started breaking my most sacrosanct rule: never to search on the clues. Even then, everything was still looking correct when it struck me that where I thought I had typed a Latin masculine plural, I had actually typed a Latin feminine singular. It crossed a name unknown to me (that I had not searched on yet). 

So. After spending a considerably longer time tracking down that one error than I had spent on the rest of the puzzle, I got the happy music. 

Philosophical question: if I finally got the answer by logic, does that erase all my previous cheating--which got me nowhere?
